descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course is concerned with the analysis of consumer and producer choice in market economies and with the nature of equilibria in competitive, monopolistic and imperfectly competitve markets. It also deals with the foundation of the market mechanism and analysis of welfare.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Students should have completed (or at least be familiar with) the material covered in Economics 201 and 202 (Introduction to Economics), and, at the minimum, Mathematics 214-1 (Differential Calculus). Calculus will be used extensively in the course.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The material covered in lectures will generally correspond to the material assigned in the readings, although the lectures will often present the material from a different point of view, often with calculus. Lectures should be viewed as complements to, rather than as substitutes for the reading. There will also be discussion sections. The discussion sections are an integral part of the course, and your attendance is expected. They will be used to expand on ideas presented in the text and in lectures, to discuss homework problems and as a time for you to ask questions about anything that you would like clarified. Problem assignments and due dates will be announced in class.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two midterms worth 30% each and a final worth 40%. Homework will count in borderline cases.
